animalOfTheDay.name: vulture
facts: They are known for their bald heads, which help keep them clean while feeding.
Vultures are scavenging birds of prey.
Vultures play a crucial role in ecosystems by cleaning up carcasses.
They have an excellent sense of smell.

calendar.name: turkey
facts: Wild turkeys can fly short distances at speeds of up to 55 mph.
They have excellent vision and can see in color, with a nearly 360-degree field of view.
Benjamin Franklin once proposed the turkey as the national bird of the United States.
Male turkeys, called toms, puff up their feathers and fan their tails to attract females.

calendar.name: turtle
facts: The gender of many turtle species is determined by the temperature of the nest.
They can breathe through their butts (cloacal respiration) when hibernating underwater.
Some turtles, like the leatherback, can dive to depths of over 4,000 feet.
Turtles have been around for over 200 million years, outliving the dinosaurs.

calendar.name: umbrellabird
facts: They have one of the deepest voices in the bird world, producing loud, booming calls.
Umbrellabirds get their name from the distinctive umbrella-like crest on the male's head.
They are found only in the rainforests of Central and South America.
Males gather in groups called leks to perform courtship displays for females.

calendar.name: vampire bat
facts: Vampires run on ground using folded wings as front legs.
Bat saliva contains draculin – an anticoagulant studied for stroke treatment.
They use infrared sensors on noses to detect blood vessels.
Vampire bats share regurgitated blood with starving colony members – reciprocal altruism.

calendar.name: vicuna
facts: Inca royalty wore vicuña robes; illegal poaching still threatens populations.
Vicuñas produce the finest wool – fibers measure 12 micrometers (human hair: 75).
They have lower incisor teeth that grow continuously like rodents.
Vicuñas spit foul-smelling cud at competitors during disputes.

calendar.name: viper
facts: Horned vipers in deserts move via sidewinding to avoid hot sand.
Vipers have heat-sensing pits detecting temperature changes as small as 0.003°C.
Gaboon vipers have longest fangs (2 inches) and highest venom yield.
Their hinged fangs fold against the roof of mouth when not striking.

calendar.name: vulture
facts: They are known for their bald heads, which help keep them clean while feeding.
Vultures are scavenging birds of prey.
Vultures play a crucial role in ecosystems by cleaning up carcasses.
They have an excellent sense of smell.

randomAnimals.name: wallaby
facts: Wallabies hop efficiently – energy use doesn't increase with speed.
Wallabies cool by licking forearms; saliva evaporation lowers blood temperature.
They practice embryonic diapause; pausing development until environmental conditions improve.
Rock wallabies scale cliffs using textured soles and tail balancing.

randomAnimals.name: fossa
facts: They have prehensile ankles that allow them to rotate their hind feet 180 degrees, making it easier to climb and descend trees headfirst.
The fossa is the largest predator of Madagascar, resembling a cat, but genetically more closely related to mongooses.
Fossas are solitary and are active both day and night.
They are very agile and can leap between trees in search of lemurs, which make up a large part of their diet.

randomAnimals.name: water buffalo
facts: Water buffaloes have wide-splayed hooves preventing sinking in mud.
They wallow in water to cool down and deter biting insects.
Domesticated for 5,000 years, they provide more milk than dairy cows in some regions.
Wild water buffaloes are endangered; only 3,400 remain in fragmented habitats.
